Updated:  
Martina, which dates from the early 1990s, is apparently based on the photo-lettering era Filmotype Hudson. Some letters in Martina like \_E\_ and perhaps \_A\_ were alt letters in the Filmotype Hudson filmstrips. The alt \_E\_ is found in the digital Filmotype Hudson as an alt \_E\_, but it does not include an alt \_A\_ like the one in Martina. The Martina \_A\_ is either an alt \_A\_ that was in the filmstrips and was missed in the Filmotype digitization, or was created by editing \_a\_ when the digital Martina was made.  
Don

Updated:  
There is also a font called Hudson which has the same \_A\_ as Martina, but the links from Identifont don't work. See [http://www.identifont.com/find?font=Hudson&q=Go](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317152605/http:/www.identifont.com/find?font=Hudson&q=Go "http://www.identifont.com/find?font=Hudson&q=Go")  
Don't know if this was pulled from sale because of legitimacy issues.  
Hudson is currently offered for sale as a FontSite Font. Again, I am not clear as to whether there are legitimacy issues.  
Further Update:  
I checked both digital Martina and FontSite digital Hudson. The Digital outlines, node positions etc. are virtually identical so one is a clone of the other. Identifont states a 1992 copyright for Hudson by The Font Company. Internal information on the Hudson font now being sold by FontSite claims a copyright of 1996. Internal information on Martina claims copyright 1990-1993 FontBank, Inc. I have no idea which dates reflect reality and who copied whom.  
Don

Recommendation. If you want to purchase a font with clear legitimacy, get Filmotype Hudson. If you want the rounded \_A\_ it's fairly simple to make. In any case, the quality is much better than Martina/Hudson.  
Don
